findings.title: The owner is a single point of failure and a centralization risk
findings.description: Having a single EOA as the only owner of contracts is a large centralization risk and a single point of failure. A single private key may be taken in a hack, or the sole holder of the key may become unable to retrieve the key when necessary.

findings.title: No function to withdraw the accidentally sent token to the contracts
findings.description: Accidentally sent tokens can be locked and will not be able to withdraw from the system.

findings.title: Used locked pragma version
findings.description: Using a locked pragma version can lead to potential security vulnerabilities and compatibility issues.

findings.title: Local Hardhat test failing
findings.description: Many tests are getting failed on Hardhat in the local env.

findings.title: SafeTransfer Methods missing
findings.description: It is good to add a require() statement that checks the return value of token transfers or to use something like a safeTransfer/safeTransferFrom unless one is sure the given token reverts in case of a failure. Failure to do so will cause silent failures of transfers and affect token accounting in the contract.

findings.title: Remove unused functions
findings.description: Unused functions can increase the contract's attack surface and should be removed.

findings.title: Recommendations and Gas optimizations
findings.description: Optimize code to reduce gas consumption.
